name: Geometry Wars: Retro Evolved
description: Geometry Wars: Retro Evolved is a old school style shooter, but remixed for the 21st century with next generation graphics and deep, modern gameplay. Playing is simple: you are a geometric "ship" trapped in a grid world, facing off against waves of deadly wanderers, snakes, and repulsars.
minimum_requirements: Windows XP, 1 GHz 32-bit (x86) or 64-bit (x64) CPU, 512MB RAM, DirectX 9.0c, DirectX Video Card (128MB memory - Shader Model 2.0 support required), DirectSound-compatible sound card, 150MB free HD space, WEI Rating: 4.0 (3.0 required)

TLDR: This is an arcade-esque twin stick shooter. It's worth the $4, but you'll need a controller to play it right.  This game was a launch title for the Xbox 360 when it first launched in 2005. Yet due to its simplicity still holds up today. Take control of a shape as you shoot other shapes in hopes to get as high of a score as possible. But beware as the waves of enemies get bigger and faster the longer you stay alive. It's a test not only of dexterity, but also of endurance. While this version lacks the retro mode the 360 version had, it's not really that much of an oversight as the Evolved mode will still have you hooked. You may play in small doses, but it's a game you'll be coming back to again and again and again and again and again and again and again.  Should you buy this: Yes, but ONLY if you have a controller. It's a twin stick shooter, so that should go without saying. You could theoretically play this with a mouse and keyboard, but just because you can doesn't mean you should. If you have Windows 8/10 you can hook up an Xbox One controller and it instantly hooks up.  Worth: $4 is a fair price, although you can usually get about a dollar off if you wait until it goes on sale (it doesn't happen often though)

This game has a simple premise: you simply move your ship around, and shoot at the baddies, quite similar to that old game Asteroids. Geometry Wars starts off easy, but once you hit around 10000 points, it really starts picking up and getting harder. There are two weapon upgrades you get, that alternate every 10000 points. A rapid fire machine gun thing, and wide shot. You also have a bomb that can kill all enemies on the screen at once. Yes, you will need to use it. There are many varieties of enemies, from the type that simply float around, to big long snakes that you have to hit in the head to kill, to those green squares that continually try to ram you and are smart enough to dodge your fire. It is a beautiful game: all retro graphics, with very nice anti-aliasing and wonderful multi-color explosions. I strongly recommend purchasing this game if you love a fast paced arcade-style game, with wonderful visuals, and brilliant 'just one more try' game play. LordWildMan score: 5/5

This is retro-style twin-stick shooter fun, though it's no Robotron 2084. (I think having only 8 directions would actually make moving and shooting easier to control, but whatevs). The design of the game doesn't appeal to me, though the pacing is pretty good. It is an exciting shooter, but the graphics, sound and music are a bit too flashy (literally) to me.  A mildly recommended rating, great as a casual time-killer. But I think there might be better games with more interesting goals and gameplay, such as Geometry Wars 3.

If you're looking for the action in an arcade shooter, and the adrenaline pumping excitement of Geometry, then you have found the right game. Geometry Wars: Retro Evolved is a replica of how people learned their Geometry in the 1800's. You got squares, you got circles, you got a coordinate plane, you got kites, you got parallelograms, you even got triangles. What more would you want out of a game? If you're a Geometry student, I highly recommend this game for studying.   9/10 -Renegawd

Control your daring C-shaped object in battling hordes of evil diamonds, blocks, pinwheels, circles, and other nefarious objects in a quest for survival. In other words, you shoot things.

An intense twin shooter that requires split second reactions and crowd management. You can go from facing a handful of enemies to being flooded in essentially a 'bullet hell' barrage of shapes that are trying to kill you. You will die over and over again before you get good, but that is the point. The line between failure and success is so thin that you are almost always overwhelmed by the game’s breakneck pace. I have been playing the game since 2006 and don't think I will ever get over how frenetic it is.
